Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Genetic improvement of loblolly pine wood for increased density
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project will be to increase wood production of managed loblolly pine tree farms by 20%. Global demand for forest industry products, e.g., pulp for paper, saw timber, and wood pellets for fuel, is expected to rise 60-100% by 2060. As the world's 4th largest exporter of forest products, the U.S. is well positioned to help meet these growing needs. To do so, managed loblolly pine tree farms will play a large role in supplying the demand. Using a biotechnology gene trait approach to introduce cell wall gene technology, the goal is to engineer pine trees with 20% more wood density over conventional crops. This may result in more wood material per tree, per acre with no added cost to production processing, i.e., no increase use of land, water, or fertilizers. As an added benefit, bioengineered trees with cell wall gene technologies aid in protecting the environment by sequestering more atmospheric CO2 thus helping to combat the negative effects of global climate change. Ultimately, this work may lead to the development of renewable materials needed to meet societal needs while helping to protect the environment.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase (SBIR) I project proposes to evaluate the use of a biotechnology gene trait approach to bioengineer loblolly pine for high wood density by modifying secondary cell wall gene regulation. The proposed research would utilize a newly adapted pine transformation protocol to introduce cell wall gene platform technologies, together with ubiquitously expressed and secondary wall-specific promoters, to significantly and selectively increase cell wall density in loblolly pine. Bioengineered plants will be selected using herbicide resistance and the effects of transgene incorporation analyzed through gene expression and histochemical analysis. The anticipated outcome of this project will be 400 bioengineered pine seedlings with greater strength and increased value to be tested in greenhouse and field trials once approved. This project will serve as proof-of-concept testing for select cell wall gene technologies in commercial tree crops towards technology commercialization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Forest products, i.e., pulpwood for paper and sawtimber for lumber, play an important role in our society particularly as it relates to the economy. In the U.S., these wood products add nearly $50 billion to the gross domestic product (GDP) with two-thirds of this material being supplied from commercial plantations of southern yellow pine. To meet the rising domestic and international demands for forest products, innovative solutions to produce more wood using less resources, i.e., land, water, and fertilizer, is key.

            At Genoverde, our research is designed to address the increasing demand for wood using a biotechnology (or engineering) approach to increase wood density in southern pine. For wood products, wood density determines its end use; ultimately determining its value. Low density wood is used to make paper products while high density wood is used for lumber and other structural materials. With our approach, we improve the growing ability of southern pine to produce wood faster which allows commercial farmers to harvest sooner without compromise to wood volume or quality.

            During this SBIR Phase I award, we investigated whether our gene technology would increase wood density in southern pine. A major obstacle in achieving this goal was that the ability to engineer southern pine is very time consuming and often inefficient. A large part of our work during this award was to establish an improved and streamlined method for growing pine in the greenhouse to confirm the effects of our technology. Significant efforts to identify the correct laboratory conditions, including the appropriate nutrient, lighting, and temperature conditions, were explored to optimize the pine engineering protocol. To this end, we have made significant progress in identifying the correct conditions however we continue to improve upon our efforts in order to further simplify and speed up the process.

            The results from our Phase I award suggest that our gene technology increases wood density in southern pine in early development. The results show that the expression of genes tightly associated with wood production in pine are upregulated in plants with our gene technology as compared to control (non-engineered) plants. In addition, data shows that plants with our gene technology have thicker cell walls. Cell walls are structural parts in plant cells where wood (also known as cellulose or sugar) is developed. Due to the relatively slow growth nature of pine, our results are based on early developmental stages of this plant. Going forward we expect to continue to study the longer-term effects of our technology, in pine as it matures, to more accurately determine the wood density benefits as they relate to our gene technology. 

 


Last Modified: 01/02/2018
Modified by: Michael J Harrington
